nodeFaq.title: Is it true that people metabolize drugs at different rates and that this correlates with "racial" groupings?

field_question_summary.processed: What about data that suggest differences in vulnerabilities to illness, metabolism of alcohol, opiates, and other drugs among racial groupings? Should drug manufacturers not assume that clinical trials performed on Whites are generalized to all populations?

field_expert_1.processed:
People do metabolize drugs at different rates, and this is due to many factors, only some of which are genetic. Drug metabolism can be influenced by the rate at which drugs are transported into cells, the rate at which they are broken down inside of cells, the rate at which they are excreted, etcetera. Genes influence these processes because these processes are conducted by enzymes and transport proteins. However, environmental factors also play a strong role. Diet, for instance, may increase the production of a relevant enzyme. It may provide co-factors that allow the enzyme to act more efficiently or it may inhibit an enzyme.

For some drugs or classes of drugs, studies have shown differences in the statistical mean drug response between study subjects from different races. For instance, one review article reported that there is a statistically significant difference between white people (of some nationality) and Chinese people (one nationality of Asian people) in the amount of the anticoagulant warfarin needed to maintain a therapeutic dose. The average dose for Chinese people was 50% less than the average dose for white people. Yet, these data directly contradict what the genetic data predict. We know of at least one gene that has a significant effect on warfarin metabolism, and we know which versions of the gene produce efficient warfarin metabolism in the test tube. If we only looked at genetics, we would think that white people would need, on average, less of the drug to obtain a therapeutic dose. (Xie, et al., "Molecular Basis of Ethnic Differences in Drug Disposition and Response," Annual Rev. Pharmacol and Toxicol. 2001. 51:815-50.) Furthermore, studies have shown that Japanese people (a nationality of Asian people) in Japan require a lower dose of warfarin than Japanese people in the US to achieve a therapeutic dose. (Id. p.818)

This example highlights the important point that when we see racial differences in some medical outcome, we should not assume that the differences are genetic. This example also reminds us how difficult it is to make categorical claims about drug metabolism and people of any particular race and ethnicity. In any given study, the answers you get may depend on which white people or which Asian people or which black people you are studying. Are these new immigrants or people who are deeply acculturated to mainstream U.S. lifestyles? Are these white people in the United States or in France, or Chinese people in China or the United States? The answer may also depend on whether you are studying people who are a majority or a minority. And whether you are studying people who are wealthy or poor. All of these features can make a difference in medical outcome, including drug metabolism. The problem is that these environmental features often co-vary with race, making it difficult to determine the exact explanation for observed differences between racial groups.

Frankly, I think that scientists have a responsibility not to over interpret statistically unreliable data, which is what has happened a lot recently - claims are made on the basis of data that are not statistically significant, and claims are made on the basis of one experiment. This is irresponsible because such data might be misleading and one experiment generally cannot sort out all possible causal explanations. It's dangerous to assume that if you see a difference it's due to genetics. When you don't know the explanation, you have to be very careful about making essentialist claims - that what was true for this study will always be true - that Japanese people, for example, will always need less warfarin than white people. It may not always be true.
